reasoning: The critique targets a key step in the paper’s case that unbounded linear views are “fussy”: the move from (i) value-efficiency is fat-tailed to (ii) therefore the set of resource uses within ~50% of optimal is tiny, so mostly-great futures require extremely specific configurations. If that inference fails, one major plank for linear-view fussiness weakens. However, it would not refute the overall “no easy eutopia” position, which also relies heavily on other mechanisms (moral-catastrophe fragility/product-of-factors model; arguments about bounded views and bads sensitivity; broader moral uncertainty considerations). The objection is philosophically apt—fat tails can coexist with broad near-optimal plateaus—so it does put real pressure on the cited pivot, but it remains largely a possibility claim without concrete support (e.g., a model of future design spaces showing many near-optima, or reasons to expect smooth/robust value landscapes), so it only moderately weakens the targeted premise. Relevance is decent because it engages a substantive Tier-2-style assumption in Forethought’s framework (fat-tailed value-per-resource driving narrow-target conclusions), though it doesn’t connect to an explicitly flagged Tier-3 internal tension or propose an empirical/decision-relevant discriminator.
title: "Broad Plateaus Can Undermine Needle Targets"
